w:r.w:t: Create a standard Gradle ‘application’ project in IntelliJ for your client
We will set the client up to make a GET call to
You can debug both the servlet and the client simultaneously, by running the servlet on your computer using
The code to make a simple GET call and write the response body to the console is as follows – put it in a method called something like
// Read the body of the response
The code above can throw exceptions, so it will prompt you to either throw the exception further up the call
handle the exception with a try-catch block. Do the second of these.
Run the code so that this method gets called – you should see the imperial website html displayed on the console.

// The message to send the servlet

, run the client in another instance of IntelliJ, putting the servlets address into the URL above, and get the client to
. The client should have output the reply from the servlet to its console.

w:r.w:t: – it will host our servlet. One of the most popular is called Heroku, but that has brought in the requirement to enter a payment card number, even though students get
usage. See Appendix A for more information on Heroku
if you wish to use it
has set up another cloud server called Tsuru, which does not need a payment card, so we will use that. We will set up a “
Action” to build and test our servlet and if successful then deploy to the Tsuru cloud server.
Click New->Directory from the root of your servlet project and call
(include the full stop at the start) and then create a New->Directory under
and paste in the text on the next page.
that has been emailed to your group
with the actual name of your .war file which can be found in
repo for your servlet, click ‘Settings->Secrets and Variables->Actions’ – add a Repository secret called TSURU_HOST and give it the value ‘https://impaas.uk’
, and add another secret called TSURU_TOKEN and give it the value of the token already emailed to your group.
. Under ‘Actions’ for that repo, you should see on the left ‘Deploy to Tsuru’ as an Action. From this page you should be able to see a real-time log of the building, testing and deploying
every time you push the project to
If all has been successful, wait 60 seconds and the servlet should be available at
Note – there is only one app available for each group
currently due to the resources available on the Dept of Computing cluster
you will need to take it in turns
please let each other know when you
deploy your app and trying things out.
This may improve during the term – it’s the first time
Trigger on push to the main branch. Change this as needed.
How to set up a Heroku server for cloud deployment
CAUTION: This requires a credit/debit card number. Students can get a certain amount of access for free each year
We are now going to set up auto-deployment to the Heroku cloud server. This creates a ‘pipeline’, so that any changes you push to
are deployed to the cloud server without any further effort.

When the war file is running on the Heroku server, it can be accessed from web clients and browsers, but Heroku can scale so that there would be no problem if your app went viral and millions started using it (although you would start paying for it!)
If you have not yet set up a Heroku account: set up a Heroku student account. (Make sure that you originally created a
-for-students account with an Imperial College email address, and that you use it to set up your Heroku account). Use the link from the Heroku tool on this
student account you will be given free credits by Heroku to last one year running
‘Eco-dyno’ servlet and one mini-Postgres database full time. Please see the FAQ details on the following page, and watch the
lease make sure that you are using no more than “Eco Dynos plan ($5 for 1000 dyno hours/month), one Mini Heroku Postgres database ($5/month)”.

dyno (that runs your servlet) stays live for 30 minutes after it is last accessed before going to sleep). If you are waiting for your Heroku account to be approved, you can continue with the rest of this tutorial anyway using the local
Heroku does not actually run a webserver for you. Instead, the way to run a servlet ‘.war’ file on Heroku is to upload it, together with a jar file that
a webserver called webapp-runner. Download the following file:
and add it to the root of your project in IntelliJ, and push it to
Setting up the servlet for Heroku deployment
Add a text file to the root of your project (and add to git) called
(that is the complete filename - there is no .txt extension) that contains the following line,
putting in the name of your war file found in the build/libs folder instead of
Create a text file in the root of your project (and add to git) called
file in the root of your project so that it just contains the word build.
Commit and push the project to
To create the corresponding project in Heroku (assuming your account has been activated
Create an app name that matches your repo name (remember it had no spaces)
When the app has been created, check that you are on the ‘Deploy’ tab, and then under ‘Deployment method’, click the ‘
’ option (not Heroku git). Search for and then select your project’s repo.
Click ‘Enable Automatic Deploys’ when it appears.
Now, every time you push to the
repo main branch, Heroku should automatically clone your repo, build your project and then deploy it.
You should now be able to browse to your Heroku deployment webpage from a browser using the ‘Open app’ button at the top of the Heroku page. This is now the persistent link to your app.
Now, every time you push to
master branch, Heroku should deploy the new version without you having to do anything. You can watch this build and deployment happen on the ‘Activity’ tab in Heroku.
